messageBody:
JUnit Testing Standards

>   Date: Wed, 11 Apr 2001 14:01:16 -0000
>   From: nixj14@...
>Subject: JUnit Testing Standards
>
>I've been placed in charge of learning the concepts of JUnit and
>reporting them back to our team.  I've reviewed many of the messages
>in this archive and in the extreme progrogramming group archive.  I
>haven't been able to find any Testing Standards besides those
>compiled in the "JUnit Best Practices" article.  Are there any
>standards for validation or any general standards that anyone has
>incorporated in their own projects?  The thought behind this is by
>alligning everyone into some basic testing standards we can document
>the process and use it as a requirements doc.

Testing standards are specific to every team that does testing. Your team probably should write up recommendations (or "standards"), but your team's requirements would be different than another team.

Extreme Programming states that you should ask yourself "what could possibly go wrong" when you are writing code test-first. If you are writing satellite software, and are concerned that gamma rays will corrupt memory, then your definition of "possibly go wrong" are different from someone writing a simple game.
